Aizu Shoami from Torigo=
ye, 'Tsuba, An Aesthetic Study', abridged:

"By the Genroku era, and after,=
 we have ample evidence of this school 
in the mass production of inferior =
quality tsuba.  This work is 
little better than shiiremono.  The style of =
this period was a 
combination of Shoami and later Umetada school styles. .=
..  The poor 
quality of Aizu Shoami tsuba is partially due to the fact tha=
t for 
two hundred and twenty six years the Kato family governed this 
prov=
ince without giving their patronage to the Shoami artists who 
lived there.=
  They made no effort to raise the level of the work 
produced, or take an =
interest in its production. The workers of the 
province were forced, as in=
dependent artists, to fend for themselves, 
seeking work anywhere it might =
be available.  ...  At the end of the 
Edo age there were two wholesale dea=
lers of 'saikumono' (metal 
handiwork) living at Wakamatsu in Aizu.  They e=
mployed many workers 
to fill the orders for the mass productions of the Ai=
zu Shoami 
school. ... In Meiji/Taisho they produced all types of copies an=
d 
imitations for the Tokyo and foreign market.  In addition to the Aizu 
s=
tyle they made Heianjo brass inlay and Heianjo openwork, as well as 
Nobuiy=
e, Kaneiye, shingen and famous late kinko artist forgeries and 
imitations.=
  In fact, they made any and all styles that had a ready 
market with the f=
oreigners of Europe and America.  This was the final 
fate of the Aizu Shoa=
mi school".

Personally I wouldn't draw a comparison with Bungo as they wer=
e a 
very legitimate area of sword production and these became outright 
fo=
rgeries and reproductions of poor quality in later Edo.
